data.text: Is It Safe to Bicycle Tour as a Single Woman?

Hi all, I‚Äôve been reading and learning from everyone‚Äôs posts. I‚Äôm inspired and hoping to actually do a bike tour myself some day. My question is more for single women‚Ä¶ do you tour on your own? And do you feel safe doing so? (Do you camp which would be my preference, or do you find lodging?)
I camp by myself though I bring my dog ( less for protection as he is useless as a guard dog and more just to have something to talk to
data.author: Lora Tryon

data.text: can I ask how you bring your dog? Trailer? Back pack? How big is the dog? I am sure they would protect you if only by tripping them over during their enthusiastic welcome ( that is the only chance we have with ours)
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: He runs/walks alongside he‚Äôs 65 pounds and has failed polite people greetings as he has no filter and loves everyone. He‚Äôs getting older so only bring him for shorter trips or car camping now. He won‚Äôt get in a trailer or ride in one so he stays with family or friends now
data.author: Lora Tryon

data.text: love the no filter, that is a serious sized dog. Hopefully he gets to enjoy many more trips
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: I camp and find lodging.
data.author: Carrielynn O'Reilly

data.text: I toured Europe for 4 months on my own, if somewhere felt dodgy, I moved on or stayed in a hotel, if there were camp grounds I stayed there, and occasionally wild camped. Never felt unsafe
data.author: Andrea Rose

data.text: Not a woman, but most people assume I am üôÑ and I draw plenty of misogyny and queer+transphobia on top of it. Yes, I tour and camp on my own and love doing it. Being white probably affords me some circumstantial protection. I don't feel any less safe while touring than I do in my daily existence.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I camp by myself
data.author: Aj Sake

data.text: As a "darker" or hippy-like man, I've sometimes been turned away when requesting to pitch my tent at a farmer's place. There's always "a better place a bit further up the road," to the point that I stop asking anymore, but always with the feeling that it would be different, less threatening for them or more an occasion for them to be "protective" if I were a woman or were accompanied by one.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I think it would someone depend on what country you are going touring in. Which country do you live in?
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: US, southern area
data.author: Graeme Tucker

data.text: , I live in a different country to you so I don‚Äôt know but I am sure that will help get you a more accurate answer. I.e. do females feel safe touring alone in US southern area camping/ staying in accommodation.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: I realized that after the fact üòÅ
data.author: Graeme Tucker

data.text: , very lucky here in Queensland, Australia. The answer to your question here would be yes, perfectly safe.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: I'm assuming you are male. If so, how could you possibly know that it is perfectly safe for women anywhere?
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: , because of friends that ride and walk in the same place as me. Because I take my daughters touring (11 and 13 years) and we camp in free camps in parks and in the bush, the last time, last week over Easter. Because I meet and talk to other people that come along (male & female). Because I have also been to places where it is not safe and understand the contrast. As stated, I have no experience or knowledge of the area that the op will be touring in.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: Aaron. My point is that you are male, therefore you cannot possibly know what the lived experience of single females is. It's called male privilege. ie. It is invisible to you.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: Check out some of the women's bikepacking groups. You will find solid relevant advice & lots of support there too.
data.author: Gracie Trish

data.text: I tour on my own and camp. I mostly felt safe. There were a few instances where I didn‚Äôt and I biked longer days to get to a campground I felt safer in.
data.author: Meghan Bridget

data.text:
I just finished a 38-day solo tour and posted a summary on my blog. www.vibesvoyager.wordpress.com On that trip I only felt unsafe in one instance at a campground. I reported the sketchy dude and was able to move to another campground. I mainly use Warmshowers because that feels super safe, and hike/bike campsites when I don‚Äôt use Warmshowers. I also use Host A Sister üåé to find safe accommodation as well
Carolyn's Collections
vibesvoyager.wordpress.com
data.author: Carolyn Stallard

data.text: there a korean girl m( now lady) that's has been touring for over 10 years by herself> has lots of video's up on YouTube .
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: Im a female solo cycling traveller and currently in the USA. I have to say that i have some trouble feeling safe myself. The campgrounds are sometimes a bit scary, because theres no one around, just people living in their car. But i really hope that changes when the camping season really starts. What is your route, ill be happy to meet en ride somewhere together?
data.author: Lotte Veerman

data.text: hey I‚Äôm also cycling the us right now. I always wild camp. Do you pay anything at campgrounds or is it for free? Or can you sneak in? üôÇ
data.author: Lovisa Tillgren

data.text: Hi . Great, where are you at the moment? Im nog wild camping because im too scared at the moment. I stay a lot at hosts and that is actually really nice. If i stay at a campground i do pay for it
data.author: Lotte Veerman

data.text: I'm wondering why you want to know about single women's experiences.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: did you check out the OP‚Äôs profile photo?
data.author: Alice JT

data.text: because the experience of women (and other people targeted by misogynist violence) cycling alone is very different to that of cis men. The potential for various types of abuse and sexual violence is much higher.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: whoops. My mistake.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: whoops. That's why I asked. I made the assumption that the poster was male.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: Yes I often go on my own and camp. I feel safe too.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: I solo bike toured Europe for 6 months, 10,000 km. Camped at campgrounds when I could‚Ä¶true to camp next to families or other campers. When campgrounds not available there‚Äôs always a church, cemetery, corn field or nice home willing to take you in. Just stop and ask someone who‚Äôs outside if u can fill up your water bottle‚Ä¶starts conversation. Watch out for the overnight ferries. They have female dorms on board for solo women travelers that are safer than camping on the deck. And remember, In Europe, being asked to coffee is not just coffee. üòÇ I also carried mace.
data.author: Andrea Larson

data.text: I am cycling solo in central America. I haven't felt unsafe , only camped in parks with security guards , gas stations . Also used couch surfing and warm showers. the rest of the time I've been taken in and fed by lovely families üòä
data.author: Julie Neville

data.text: Check out this fb page https://www.facebook.com/groups/womenwhobikepack/permalink/730640818300973/
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: I don't stay in primitive campgrounds when no one is around. People can show up in ATV's and locals know where the back roads are.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: Hi I‚Äôm cycling the Pacific Coast Highway 1/101 - I love touring solo and have no worries about tenting at campgrounds or staying with Warm Shower hosts. The west coast has Hiker/Biker campsites $5, $7, $10 depending on the state park
data.author: Barbara Appleby

data.text: I'm keen on this ride...is the road reasobably safe to cycle on, how busy?..good verge etc..I don't carry a tent ...is there accomodation at hotel...hostel etc atleast every 50 miles...thankyou Kiwi Kelly üö≤
data.author: Kelly Bryant

data.text: hi weekdays not so busy. Sometimes Hwy 1 is better - less hills and speeding vehicles than 101. Join Warm Showers better accommodation than State Parks though sometimes you will have to camp as there‚Äôs no other choice. Also 50 miles per day may not be possible due to huge hills but maybe you are stronger cyclists than me and carry less weight. Sometimes no verge so you need to be assertive in your 1/3 of lane. This year many hostels still closed (dorm beds) due to Covid though not Santa Monica.
data.author: Barbara Appleby

data.text: thanku...so very helpful ‚ò∫
data.author: Kelly Bryant

data.text: I recommend you look at the ACA Adventure Cycling Association maps and the guide book to see what options you have. I had good temperatures for March and April upto San Francisco then I rode to Santa Rosa on 101 temperatures still good. These last 3 nights cycling Hwy 1 from Bodega Bay to Gualala it‚Äôs been quite cold ü•∂
data.author: Barbara Appleby

data.text: Thats gr8 thanku so much...will check it out..I've cycled al over New Zealand where I'm from...keen 2 come ova 2 states nx year...also looking at great american railtrail...so much to see ....thanku again üöµ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üö¥‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
data.author: Kelly Bryant
